dc:description:
*KYNU* was first reported in relation to autosomal recessive vertebral, cardiac, renal, and limb defects syndrome 2 in 2017 (Shi H, et al., 2017, PMID: 28792876) but was previously identified with hydroxykynureninuria in 2007 (Christensen M, et al., 2007, PMID: 17334708). Congenital defects found in VCRL2 include segmentation defects, cardiac defects such as hypoplastic heart, hypoplastic kidneys, missing kidneys, clinodactyly, radial deviation, and polydactyly. Evidence supporting this gene-disease relationship includes case-level data and experimental data. At least 14 unique variants (e.g. missense, nonsense, frameshift, splicing, and large deletion) have been reported in 11 probands from 5 publications (PMIDs: 28792876, 33942433, 31923704, 17334708, 34200361). Variants in this gene segregated with disease in 1 additional family member. The gene *KYNU* encodes Kynureninase, one of the enzymes responsible for the biosynthesis of NAD from Trpytophan. This gene-disease association is further supported by its biochemical function in the kynurenine pathway (PMID: 8706755) and a knockout mouse model (PMID: 28792876) which recapitulates the phenotype on a NAD-restricted diet. In summary, *KYNU* is definitively associated with autosomal recessive vertebral, cardiac, renal, and limb defects syndrome 2. This has been repeatedly demonstrated in both the research and clinical diagnostic settings, and has been upheld over time.

This gene-disease pair was originally evaluated by the Aminoacidopathy GCEP on 07/10/2020. It was reevaluated on 08/01/2022. As a result of this reevaluation, the classification increased from Moderate to Definitive with the addition of 5 new cases (PMIDs: 33942433 and 34200361).

evidence.dc:description: Insertion of the human KYNU coding sequence into a eukaryotic expression vector yielded relatively high amounts of the active enzyme in human embryonic kidney HEK-293 cells. KYNU activity was measured spectrophotometrically by formation of anthranilic acid and 3-hydroxyanthranilic acid quantified at 313 nm and 420 nm, respectively. The Km values of L-kynurenine and DL-3-hydroxykynurenine for the recombinant enzyme were 671 +/- 37 uM and 13.2 +/- 2.0 uM, respectively.

The role of KYNU in the kynurenine pathway, catalyzing the reaction L-3-hydroxykynurenine + H2O = 3-hydroxyanthranilate + L-alanine, is consistent with the elevated hydroxykynurenine and NAD deficiency observed in patients, as this subpathway is part of the NAD(+) biosynthesis pathway.

Given the various roles of NAD, there are many possible ways (given its central role in energy metabolism, regulation of sirtuin-mediated deacetylation, and DNA repair) by which a deficit might disrupt embryogenesis and cause congenital malformations.
evidence.rdfs:label: Enzymatic activity

evidence.dc:description:
Kynu-/- embryos were normal but had 70x 3-Hydroxyanthranilic acid levels compared to wildtype. The NAD(H) levels were similar in all mice which may be explained by the fact that in mice, reduced niacin status occurs only when both de novo synthesis of NAD is blocked and niacin is removed from the diet. 

When mice were put on a NAD-restricted diet null embryos recapitulated human phenotypes including defects in vertebral segmentation, heart defects, small kidney, cleft palate, talipes, syndactyly, and caudal agenesis. Developmental defects correlated inversely with nicotinic acid supplementation in null mice. In summary, KYNU null phenotypes provide evidence that KYNU function and resulting NAD level in embryo is involved in producing phenotypes found in congenital malformations.
Kynu-/- embryos were normal but had 70x 3-Hydroxyanthranilic acid levels. The NAD(H) levels were similar in all mice.
evidence.rdfs:label: Kynu KO mouse
F4.II.2
evidence.detectionMethod:
Trio WES. The entire KYNU protein-coding region was covered at a minimum read depth of 10, and no multi-exon deletions or duplications
were identified.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: stillborn at a gestational age of 28 weeks
evidence.previousTestingDescription:
Microarray (CytoSNP-850K Illumina Inc) was normal. CNV analysis was performed using exome data but nothing of note
was identified.

evidence.dc:description: His263Arg is homozygous due to consanguinity.

Yeast homozygous for deletion of the KYNU ortholog, Bna5p were transformed with plasmids generating human WT KYNU, or His263Arg KYNU and grown in the absence of niacin for 24h. Total NAD was measured in cell lysates, finding significant reduction with mutant KYNU (57% or below that of WT KYNU; p < .001).

evidence.rdfs:label: F6.II.4
evidence.detectionMethod:
Hybridization-based exome capture sequencing.  Sanger sequencing was
used to confirm candidate causal variants.
evidence.previousTestingDescription:
Chromosomal microarray analysis revealed a 2.88 Mb gain at
22q11.21 (chr21:18,916,842-21,800,797; hg19) inherited from the father (F6.I.1). Whole exome sequencing analysis also identified a
heterozygous NM_001329630.1(PLEKHA7):c.571G>A p.(Asp191Asn) variant inherited from the father, which was
confirmed by Sanger sequencing

Yeast homozygous for deletion of the KYNU ortholog, Bna5p were transformed with plasmids generating human WT KYNU, or Lys121del KYNU and grown in the absence of niacin for 24h. Total NAD was measured in cell lysates, finding significant reduction with mutant KYNU (57% or below that of WT KYNU; p < .001).

evidence.rdfs:label: Schule Patient
evidence.detectionMethod: Trio-Exome analysis and CGH array analysis in combination with long range PCR.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: increased xanthurenic acid excretion in the urine
evidence.previousTestingDescription:
The karyotype was found to be normal and a standard Next Generation Sequencing gene panel analysis for ciliopathy causing genes (Bioscentia, Ingelheim, Germany) did not reveal any causative variants.

Likewise, no causative deletions or duplication were detected by CGH array analysis.

evidence.dc:description: Homozygous deletion of exon 5 (predicted to cause a frameshift and NMD) is due to maternal isodisomy of chromosome 2.

evidence.rdfs:label: Ehmke Patient 2
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: elevated urinary 3-hydroxykynurenine 7.17 (0.16 in controls), xanthurenate 4.62 (0.14 in controls), and kynurenine 1.88 (-0.39 in controls)

evidence.dc:description:
Present in gnomAD at an MAF of 0.000008791 (1/113752) in the non-Finnish European population.

Score was updated from 0.25 to 0.2 for this proband as per scoring rubric in SOPv9.

evidence.rdfs:label: Christensen Proband
evidence.detectionMethod: The  entire  coding  cDNA sequence  of  KYNU  was  amplified and sequenced. This variant was confirmed in genomic DNA.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: xanthurenic aciduria (massive urinary excretion of xanthurenic acid, 3-hydroxykynurenine, and kynurenine). xanthurenic acid 260 umol/mmol creatinine, 3-hydroxykynurenine 287 umol/mmol creatinine, and 30 umol/mmol creatinine kynurenine (all are non-detectable in control).

evidence.dc:description:
The homozygous, due to distant consanguinity, missense variant Thr198Ala was identified in this proband with hydroxykynureninuria with no congenital malformation.

This variant is present in gnomAD at an MAF of 0.0001157 (4/34564) in the Latino population.

From Shi H, et al.,2017, PMID: 28792876 -- 64% recombinant enzymatic activity was retained with 682 ± 32 µmol min-1mg-1 compared to WT at 1065 ± 35.

From Szot et al., 2021 (PMID: 33942433) --
Yeast homozygous for deletion of the KYNU ortholog, Bna5p were transformed with plasmids generating human WT KYNU, or Thr198Ala KYNU and grown in the absence of niacin for 24h. Total NAD was measured in cell lysates, finding 26% reduction with mutant KYNU (p < .05).

evidence.rdfs:label: F7.II.2
evidence.detectionMethod: Trio WES and reported variants were confirmed by Sanger sequencing.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Pregnancy was terminated at 26 weeks gestation

evidence.dc:description: GnomAD: Found in European non-Finnish population 0.0001477 (19/128610)

The frameshift in exon 6 is predicted to cause a premature stop codon in exon 7of 14 and lead to NMD. 

Should the variant escape NMD, it would be deleterious to enzymatic activity. Yeast homozygous for deletion of the KYNU ortholog, Bna5p were transformed with plasmids generating human WT KYNU, or Ala164fs KYNU and grown in the absence of niacin for 24h. Total NAD was measured in cell lysates, finding significant reduction with mutant KYNU (57% or below that of WT KYNU; p < .001).
GnomAD highest frequency Latino 0.0002322 (8/34460)

Yeast homozygous for deletion of the KYNU ortholog, Bna5p were transformed with plasmids generating human WT KYNU, or Arg428Trp KYNU and grown in the absence of niacin for 24h. Total NAD was measured in cell lysates, finding significant reduction with mutant KYNU (57% or below that of WT KYNU; p < .001).

evidence.rdfs:label: Ehmke Patient 1
evidence.detectionMethod: Array CGH detected the deletion allele and whole exome sequencing identified the missense variant.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: elevated urinary 3-hydroxykynurenine 8.89 (0.16 in controls), xanthurenate 7.06 (0.14 in controls), and kynurenine 3.74 (-0.39 in controls)

evidence.dc:description:
The missense variant Arg428Trp was not of maternal origin, however the father was not available for sequencing or confirmation. It is present in gnomAD at an MAF of 0.0002322 (8/34460) in the Latino population.

The second variant a maternally inherited GRCh37 (chr2:143634577-143719262)x1 deletion of exons 1-8 (CACN74781085). As a predicted null variant it is contributing 1.5pt toward the proband score.

From Szot et al., 2021 (PMID: 33942433) --
Yeast homozygous for deletion of the KYNU ortholog, Bna5p were transformed with plasmids generating human WT KYNU, or Arg428Trp KYNU and grown in the absence of niacin for 24h. Total NAD was measured in cell lysates, finding a significant reduction with mutant KYNU (p < .001).

evidence.dc:description: The missense variant Trp109Ser was homozygous due to consanguinity and is present in gnomAD at an MAF of 0.00002639 (3/113668) in the non-Finnish European population.

evidence.rdfs:label: F5.II.1
evidence.previousTestingDescription:
Microarray was normal and female. A gene panel for Adams-Oliver syndrome was performed, identifying a heterozygous VUS in NM_005349.4(RBPJ):c.536-24A>G inherited maternally but was not considered causative of the patient’s phenotype. 

Trio clinical exome sequencing was also
performed at Blueprint Genetics and reported in February 2020, identifying heterozygous NM_016353.5(ZDHHC2):c.685_688del p.(Phe229Alafs*6) and homozygous NM_153332.4(ERI1):c.514C>T p.(Gln172*).

Total NAD was measured in cell lysates, finding significant reduction with mutant KYNU (57% or below that of WT KYNU; p < .001).

evidence.rdfs:label: Patient D
evidence.detectionMethod: Whole exome sequencing results were confirmed by Sanger sequencing.

evidence.dc:description: Highest gnomAD allele: 0.0001399 (18/128618) in European non-Finnish

The nonsense variant in exon 6 of 14 is predicted to lead to NMD. 

Should the variant escape NMD, the truncated protein would also have greatly reduced activity in vitro; enzyme activity was measured at 2 ± 3 µmol min-1mg-1, compared to WT at 1065 ± 35.
Highest gnomAD allele frequency: 0.00006224 (8/128530) in European non-Finnish

The deletion variant is predicted to result in a frameshift (p.Phe349LysfsTer4) and premature stop codon, in exon 13 of 14, leading to NMD. 

Should the variant escape NMD, the truncated protein would also have greatly reduced activity in vitro; enzyme activity was measured at 24 ± 13 µmol min-1mg-1, compared to WT at 1065 ± 35.

evidence.rdfs:label: Patient C
evidence.detectionMethod: Whole exome sequencing results were confirmed by Sanger sequencing.

evidence.dc:description:
Homozygosity is due to consanguinity.

This variant is present in gnomAD at an MAF of 0.0002187 (5/22864) in the South Asian population.

The score increased from 2pt to 3pt for this proband due to the updated scoring rubric in SOPv9.

The splicing variant c.170-1G>T is predicted to result in a frameshift (p.Val57GlufsTer21), by skipping of exon 3, and premature stop codon, in exon 4 of 14, leading to NMD. 

Should the variant escape NMD, the truncated protein would also have greatly reduced activity in vitro; enzyme activity was 0 ± 0.1 µmol min-1mg-1 compared to WT at 1065 ± 35.
